nodes.bodyText: Can it ever be the case that both !g.isCalled() and likelihoods == null? If so, you might want to change this else if to just if so that we can get both messages when both are true.

I think the OneShotLogger should be separate from the normal logger in this class, with a clear name like oneShotLogger, so that people don't mistakenly try to write additional messages to the OneShotLogger and wonder why they don't show up.

Here too I think the OneShotLogger should be separate from the normal logger, with a clear name like oneShotLogger, so that people don't mistakenly try to write additional messages to the OneShotLogger and wonder why they don't show up.

FWIW in the situation I'm trying to untangle now, having this be repeated is actually useful.  Since there are (I think) reasonable cases where strand bias can't be computed, but in my case the fact that it came out ~350 times for a fairly small panel was a good indicator of error.  And we're not looking back through historic logs to find other samples/runs that have high rates of this log message.

I'm not sure there's any point to piggybacking on these existing tests to "cover" this warning message, since it affects only the logging and not the output. It would be better, I think, to write a 2-3 line unit test for the new generateMissingDataWarning() method that just exercises the two cases of likelihoods == null and ! g.isCalled()

nodes.bodyText: Rename logger to oneShotLogger to avoid hypothetical future confusion.
Should this one go to the regular logger? Or a separate OneShotLogger? We don't want to suppress this just because we had a site that hit the other warning above.

So here we have a regular logger instead of a OneShotLogger. I think we should be consistent: either have a regular logger in both StrandBiasBySample and DepthPerSampleHC, or a OneShotLogger in both places. For debuggability, it might actually be better to keep them both as regular loggers for now.
Erm, I assume that this was added by mistake?
